name: Beisa Oryx
description: A sturdy antelope with straight horns. Its base color is gray-brown, with a white belly. Black stripes mark the sides, front legs, and head.
spread_note: In two subspecies in eastern Africa
image_alt: Beisa Oryx, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 1.5–1.7 m; tail length 45–50 cm; shoulder height 1–1.2 m; weight 115–210 kg
attractions: Oryxes are robust antelopes with long, straight or slightly curved horns. Both males and females have them, with no color difference between sexes. The beisa oryx has straight horns up to 1.5 m long. It manages water exceptionally well, surviving for periods without drinking. It can also raise its body temperature to 46.5°C during hot daytime hours. Adult males live solitarily most of the year, joining herds of females and young only during the rut. These herds, up to 40 strong, are usually led by the most experienced female. Young follow their mother immediately after birth.
breeding: Prague Zoo first kept beisa oryxes from 1960–1963. After a break, we imported a male and three females from La Palmyre in 2000. Since then, breeding has been continuous, with 12 young raised by 2014.
